												City building games have been a staple of PC gaming since the beginning. It is a subset of the RTS genre that helped to pioneer both sandbox gameplay and the concept of nearly limitless replayability. Fastforward to the present and the genre remains very much alive and well in Tropico 3; a game that takes the foundation of the genre, adds a great deal of social and economic depth, and finally puts a Latin twist on it for good measure. Developed by Haemimont Games and published by Kalypso Media, Tropico 3 has all the features of a city-building game developed by the mainstream likes of Electronic Arts.The first thing that will grab your attention is the visual quality. Tropico 3 brings the beauty of tropical islands to life very similar to the way Far Cry did. From lush forests to arid deserts, the varying environments on a single island help to break up any visual monotony that would normally be a problem. Of course, this isn't to say that the random map generator can't and doesn't create maps with little variation. Thankfully, the game does allow you to preview the landscape before starting on a new island.If the visuals aren't impressive enough, the soundtrack will get certainly get your attention. The music attempts to capture the authentic Caribbean style and does a fairly good job of it. In fact, the only real downside to the soundtrack is that there doesn't seem to be enough tracks. You will hear the same tracks many, many times during one game, which can last for hours depending on whether you're playing in sandbox mode or a campaign.In order to maintain the game's authenticity, the majority of the voice acting is Spanish. Moreover, any immigrants or workers hired from other countries will mostly speak English. Only the voice acting that the player needs to understand is done in English with a decent Latin American accent. For example, there is a radio announcer that provides regular updates on the situation of the island.The gameplay isn't the standard city building players have come to expect from games like Sim City. Instead, Tropico 3's focus is on the social, political, and economic development of the island nation. The game introduces a few factions that the people align themselves with such as Capitalists, Communists, Nationalists, Militarists, Environmentalists, Intellectuals, and the Religious. And, the player is tasked with appeasing these factions whether by building structures such as churches or military bases, signing edicts that reduce pollution or ban contraceptives, or signing treaties with either the U.S. or the U.S.S.R.The faction system brings a lot of depth to Tropico 3, and it isn't just about increasing the happiness of the overall population. Every couple years an election is held on the island that the player must win. Appeasing a majority of the factions helps secure votes, but it's based on more than making all the factions happy. For example, a majority of the population may belong to a single faction, thus making that faction the most important focus. Knowing which factions to appease and when is crucial to getting reelected. The player can choose to give political speeches during each election, and even pick what topics to address, which can have an effect on the voters.The elections aren't the only thing to worry about it. There is also the potential for members of a faction to become rebels. If the player makes a faction angry enough, it will increase the number of rebels. Then, those rebels will attempt to sabotage infrastructure, take hostages, spread propaganda, and even assassinate El Presidente. Of course, being in good standing with the Militarists (the army) allows the player to fend off against rebel attacks, which even play out on the streets when they occur.Economically, Tropico 3 is based entirely around three major sources of revenue: industry, agriculture, and tourism. The player can use farms, which can be set to harvest a variety of crops from food to tobacco; industrial buildings, which take those crops and produce products; and/or tourism attractions, which bring people to the island who will spend money.Based on the map the player is given, some economic resources such as oil wells and mining deposits, may not be available, forcing the player to rely on other ways of growing the economy. Economic progression in Tropico 3 is a slow process, even using the 3x speed feature that's available. Moreover, it needs to be closely watched by the player because of random events that may occur. For example, throughout the game, the state of the world economy may fluctuate, causing an increase or decrease in the price of your exported goods. These events will impact the player's economy dramatically, forcing the player to take action.Tropico 3 doesn't offer a huge number of building variations or options like many city building games do, but it doesn't need to. The depth of the game doesn't stem from the cosmetic look of the buildings, but from the dizzying level of depth and customization. For example, all the farms look exactly the same, but the player can set each farm on the island to grow a different crop. Better yet, where the farm is placed affects what types of crops it can grow. Some crops grow best at high altitudes, in high humidity, or in sunny areas. Picking the right crop for the right location can make or break your economy.To add to the depth, the player can also set the wages of the workers based on the job or education level. Even better than that, players can set wages based on each individual building. For instance, the cooks at one restaurant could make $15 while the cooks at the restaurant close to the tourist's hotel could make $20. Players are also able to easily set the wages of all the cooks, regardless of which restaurant they work at, as simply as clicking a button. The same thing goes for the education level options, which allow the player to set the wage of all employees with no education, a high school education, or a college education.Player will have to deal with a variety of problems such as pollution, economic disparity, crime, housing, political unrest, foreign influence, overcrowding, extreme weather, and a variety of random events that can impact the island. Hurricanes can sweep in and destroy key buildings such as electric substations, which could create rolling blackouts across the island, reducing the output of industry buildings that require power and lowering the overall happiness of the population.Despite the game's astounding level of depth and options, however, there are a few problems that can cause headaches. For starters, the in-game tutorial is a less-than-adequate introduction to the game mechanics. It does a fine job of getting the player used to the UI and where certain information is represented, but it doesn't explain how to actually grow the economy or reduce the threat of rebellion. For example, the tutorial will tell the player how to build a farm and set a crop, but it doesn't make it clear how exactly it contributes to increasing revenue.There are also some minor control issues. For example, when selecting a building to place on the map, the player uses the middle scroll wheel to rotate the buildings orientation. However, the scroll wheel is also used to zoom in and out, which means the player needs to zoom in close enough prior to selecting a building to ensure the placement is correct.Overall, Tropico 3 should be applauded for its depth and customization. The game's visuals along with its unique and authentic soundtrack help draw the player into its Caribbean setting. And, regardless of its few problems, none of which are game-breaking, it does an excellent job of focusing on the political, social, and economic pieces of the game, each of which often affects the others in some way.

												I wasn't really a Tropico fan until this one. The original Tropico had a lot of good ideas in its individual citizens and its banana republic politics, but it was held back by technical limitations and short-sighted designs. After an odd detour with Tropico 2, the developers returned to the original concept and polished it up in a brand-new 3D engine, and the results speak for themselves.Tropico 3 places you into the spit-shined spats of a Carribbean dictator, charged with helping his hapless little island flourish. Each individual citizen is modeled with needs, jobs, opinions, and motivations, so the key to success is keeping enough of them happy (or suppressed) to achieve your own agenda. This is mostly done by building homes and services they want, and making sure they have enough money to enjoy them. You'll be building churches, clinics, restaurants, casinos, and more, in addition to the farms and factories needed to fund them.The big stumbling block of the first Tropico was that your little Tropicans couldn't be trusted to actually get ♥♥♥♥ done when it needed to be done. That's not a problem here, as your citizens spend far more of their time on their tasks and only go astray if their needs are very conspicuously not being met. And as it turns out, when your island is running like it should, the money just pours in. Even the most basic exports like excess food or meat will earn you everything you need to outfit your island. And once you get more complex industries up and running, money will never be an issue again.As a result, Tropico 3 is way, way easier than its predecessors and a lot of its contemporaries, but this is by no means a bad thing. Economic prosperity allows you a lot more freedom to build your island the way you want, with all the services and luxuries you can stuff into your borders. You'll need them too, because your citizens are noticeably pickier than in previous games and won't hesitate to turn to armed rebellion. Some scenarios lean heavier on this aspect but managing the different factions and quelling uprisings are a larger part of the game, as they should be.One very welcome feature added for this outing is the opportunity to customize your dictator. Tropico 1 let you choose his or her traits but 3 lets you give them backstories, change their outfits, and then watch them walk around and interact with the people. You can actually use your little avatar to inspire workers to work harder or give rousing speeches to the commoners. The traits also seem much more powerful this time around, and honestly work as a sort of difficulty system. Taking traits that help with scenario goals can make a huge difference, but you can also choose flaws that add a greater challenge.In the end, Tropico 3 is the game the first one should have been. The core mechanics are not very far removed; most of the buildings and edicts are the same, and the politics are virtually unchanged. But everything works the way it's supposed to, is balanced to not be so frustrating, and is presented in some charming, picturesque 3D. There's no reason to go any further back in the series than this, so if you've ever wanted to lord over your own tropical island, start here.

												Tropico 3 is two things: it's essentially an HD reskin of the first game except easier, and it's arguably a stripped down version of Tropico 4 that's more difficult.The core game is still the same good Tropico experience, and there's two campaigns' worth of unique missions that are great fun. Ultimately though, Tropico 3 is probably more for series completionists, people who were turned off by the first game's age, and/or people who want to trade the more freeform experience of Tropico 4 and 5 for a challenge. The rest of this review is about how exactly Tropico 3 differs, and how it's more difficult for it.Apart from the new buildings, edicts and other stuff in the Absolute Power expansion (which is absolutely required if you're going to play this game), the inclusion of actual roads and cars, simplified construction, and new missions, it's a remake of the original from a time before remakes were cool. It introduces a couple of neat things like deficit spending up to $10,000, a tilt-shift effect when zoomed out and an isometric view.Tropico 4 doesn't have those last two things for some reason, although it more than makes up for it since 4 really is kind of a Tropico 3.5. It runs on the same engine, the UI works pretty much the same, and it doesn't change up the gameplay much, but it simply has more content both in the base game and from its own expansion & DLCs.It's more difficult than 4, since you don't have its convenience features or raft of DLC buildings to save you from tight spots. You must select two clearly defined character strengths and flaws for your Presidente, instead of 4's more even-keeled traits that usually ended up being good. Quick building doesn't exist, which forces you to plan ahead, and you can't do missions to patch up relations with factions, superpowers, or just to get yourself out of a tight spot. The missions are oriented more around long-term goals instead of more immediate objectives, which is a nice change of pace and allows for more leeway while also not handing you as many rewards simply for playing the mission.On the flipside, the fact that construction workers no longer have to clear the foundations for new buildings and the mere existence of roads, cars and garages make the game easier than the first one. You still need to plan ahead with road and garage placement, and even then sometimes traffic will be bad, but honestly, even Tropico would have cars, wouldn't it? (The black humor is arguably more sharp than 4's humor as well, which relied a little more on references.)Weirdly, if you own both the base game and the expansion pack, you can't even launch the base game without getting a prompt to play or install the expansion. You'd want to buy and use the expansion anyway if you ever play this, but it's still weird. It appears to overwrite the EXE of the base game while still appearing as a separate game in your library.It's also weird how it actually runs worse than Tropico 4. Even maxed out on my GTX 560, it stutters. Fortunately the game as a whole can still look good.You also must make an account that is apparently separate from any existing Kalypso launcher accounts to access the online user challenges. I'm not sure if there's any life left in whatever 3 had for a community, but if you're stuck with this game for whatever reason, the user-made challenges are probably worth playing.Tropico 3 definitely has a style of its own, a pretty good one that's worth pointing out in the face of otherwise little difference from 4's meat and bones, and something that might be worth experiencing for series fans. Some miscellaneous obervations about said style:* The music is great, definitely more varied than Tropico 4 but not nearly as much as the original. It's mostly more upbeat than Tropico's, too.* Unfortunately, the map generator is pretty generic: it usually makes flat discs as opposed to the more characterized islands of the first game. 4's map generation is better with this.* It's interesting to note the difference between Presidente avatars in Tropico and Tropico 3. In Tropico, it stayed out of view because the player sitting at their computer was supposed to represent the presidente. In 3, you can move your Presidente around on the map and micromanage them if you desire.* There are immigrants from the USSR/USA that can come to Tropico in this version - I'm pretty sure you don't get American or Soviet immigrants in 4.* 3's interface has a very pretty Cold War aesthetic, but is actually a little less ergonomic than 4's. I'll take 4's efficiency any day, but I'll always miss 3's look.* The cover/banner art is the best in the series. Nothing quite matches El Presidente literally handling Tropico like his own little puppet.

												Ah Tropico, where the money is so colourful, you'll forget it's worthless :DTropico 3 is a mix of city building, (Tropical island themed) and The Sims franchise, where as filling happiness factors is key to smooth gameplay. It does well enough to fit the atmosphere of the title with radio broadcasts, spanish accents and the lavitan background music. As "El Presidente" you must get enough votes to remain in power which makes it sometimes satisfying to win the election after some hard citizens to win over, however not much else is done to deepen the voting system in the game. Once you lose an election it is game over, If you win you may continue on until the next election rinse and repeat. You are a leader of a small island nation that seems to be soverign in it's own right, owing no alleginace to any superpower.You can however do dealings with Russia or America, building favour with the Communists or Capitalists, respectivly.It boils down to how you would like to run your nation, (in each mission or map scenario) leaning towards communism, keeps your citizens happier and housing cheaper, albiet loss of export profits. If heading towards the Capitalist end of the spectrum, favoring infastructure, power plants and of course export profits. As an island nation, the economy relies on exports whether or not you are predominatly Communist or Capitalist. Much of the game is spent setting up enough housing for your population, building structures to keep certain politcal groups on the island happy enough to vote for you next election and on occasion, defending your buildings from rebel attacks.Tropican citizens turn rebel when thier satisfaction levels drop too low, clicking on an indivdual citzen will show stars next to factors that determine his happiness. These stars usally 3 factors are noted, represent what is most important to this indivual, for expample job secruity or relgious satisfaction, if these needs are not met for a while he will cease to be a citizen of Tropico and join others hiding out in the island's wilderness.Special buildings can re-educate captured rebels, turning them back into a useful workforce.Another important factor in the economic stability of the Tropican islands is tourism.Tourism can be a huge boost to your government treasury, however care should be taken when you are planning your constructon phase as location of buildings is important, an ideal resort would have garages which produce cars, readily available for quick transport, hotels, entertainmt buildings and other money making buildings found under the tourism tab.Also of note, is the tourism industry can at times cause a flood of people to land on the island, causing traffic jams and lengthy, expensive, holdups, not good for any busy island nation. Take care when expanding.This may seem like a detailed review, however I have only covered some parts of the game, there is still more and I think continuing would only create a bigger wall of text and uncover all things best left undiscovered until one actually buys this game.

TL;DR SUMMARY: Immensely enjoyable sim/city builder game with a unique atmosphere and sense of humour. Its only significant weakness is the lack of more in-depth control over buildings and parametres, which can become a bit frustrating over time, as well as few missions that are genuinely challenging once you get a good hang of how the game works. This is the only thing stopping this game from becoming an addiction for hundreds of hours, but it's still incredibly fun, and since it's also easy to get into, it may be a great first choice if you've never played a game like this and want to give it a try.FULL REVIEW: GOOOOOOOOD EVENING TROPICOOOOOOO, I AM JUANITO- I mean, I am Lib and I bring you this glorious Presidente-approved review. In Tropico 3, you will learn how to build majestic sunlit cities, how to build an epic industry bringing you insane amounts of money while trying to stop the environmentalists from drowning you in broccoli, how to keep all the citizens and various groups on your island happy you can't lololol, how to make the tiny insignificant countries called the US and USSR bend to your supreme might and give you money (called "foreign aid" for some reason but who cares about the name) and how to make tourists want to have Tropican flags over their beds. Oh, and how to not get assassinated or overthrown in a coup. And llamas.So, what kind of presidente do you want to be? Do you want to build a socialdemocratic utopia where everyone is happy and fluffy unicorns walk around the streets? Of course you can, just make sure you build up a solid economy first. Or maybe you are a distant cousin of Satan and feel like the "arrange an accident" option should be the most fun in the game? You can do that as well, but you might want to make sure that your army likes you and the secret police is doing its job, or your iron fist rule may not last very long. And in either case, issuing edicts will help you along the way, with plenty of options ranging from social security to martial law.But okay, this is getting dark, so JUANITO TIME, TROPICO NEWS TODAY. This game has a unique atmosphere unlike anything else as well as an unhealthy obsession with llamas, with its heavily sarcastic (and yet pulled off with great taste) sense of humour and the constant combination of the "paradise island" setting with some fairly dark matters. The graphics are lovely (and I'm writing this in 2017), especially nature and the ocean, but the most interesting part of this game is... sound. I mean, it's a little bittersweet - it's totally unique, in the way the music is pretty much 24/7 Latin American party hard, and as a big bonus you get the already mentioned RADIO HOST JUANITO, TROPICO NEWS TODAY and whoever voiced that guy deserves a Nobel prize for voice acting (I don't care if there isn't one, make one). Still... as fun as the music is, I feel it could use a bit more variety (I think there aren't even 10 songs altogether) and as much as Juanito's lines will probably crack you up, he has only one for every particular event. By the time you have 5 hours played, the "spiraling into debt" one will be burned into your mind.But between all those things, comes my favourite thing about Tropico 3 - as simplified and "tongue in cheek" as it may be, it gives you a decent idea what ruling is like. There is always stuff to be done, nearly always someone unhappy (the results of which can vary from a small peaceful protest to an invasion) and always room for improvement. If you ever get a comfortable lead that lets you just sit back and relax, it's usually when you're near completing the mission anyway. As a result, this game does the "just 5 more minutes" syndrome probably better than anything I've ever played - you'll just want to complete that bunch of apartment blocks, oh wait the religious people are unhappy let's build a cathedral- OMGWTFBBQ REBELS I NEED AN ARMORY, okay that's done but the entertainment happiness is poor, let's build a cinema or something- ...♥♥♥♥ it's 5 AM. And the cool thing is that the game is generally very "newbie-friendly" and even though it all may sound very complex, it's quite easy to get the hang of.However, this leads us also to my biggest issue with the game - once you're past that point and know the game well, you'll wish for some more in-depth manual control over various buildings to get things done even more efficiently... but there aren't really any - especially construction workers (though thankfully you can set building priority) and teamsters work in mysterious ways that I don't think even the greatest minds could explain, and farms having half the planet of fertile land around will sometimes pick the most nonsensical spot to plant crops. And in case of statistics and such, the almanac generally does its job very well, but could be a bit more intuitive and detailed, e.g. the various happiness levels - for instance, healthcare quality or liberty are relatively easy to understand, but I still have no clue what exactly affects environmental happiness, and there is no tab with all the "pluses" and "minuses" like with the happiness of each citizen group.Speaking of which, that's one of the most fun and sometimes challenging parts - a big part of the game is balancing between the happiness of the various citizen groups, as of course they don't exactly all get along (such as capitalists and communists, for example...), as well as keeping good relations with the "superpowers" (US and USSR). The missions tend to expand that even further, as you'll encounter various events and your decisions will usually impact your relations with some of the groups or the foreign powers. The events are generally fun and cleverly designed, with the biggest plus being that your decisions usually do have an impact and further consequences, as you'll learn (you made a shady deal that seemed profitable? Well, someone found out about it). And the missions are generally quite fun and somewhat diverse (from "transform this boring island into a lovely tourist resort" to "screw everything, just get money in your Swiss bank acount"), although I really feel the later ones should be more challenging - only one leaves you with a limited choice of buildings at first forcing you to think out of the box, whereas for the rest you'll usually find out a reliable strategy at some point USSR development aid edict OP and it may start to feel a little "rinse and repeat" over time.There are two more minor issues with the game I need to mention though, just because of how... bizarre they are. The first one is that many workplaces require employees with a particular education and/or particularly men or women... and especially at the beginning when you have few citizens, the latter can be annoying. Now... it's not surprising priests need to be male or, um, cabaret workers need to be female, but... only men can be doctors (the most consistently annoying one), only women can be high school teachers but only men can teach in colleges, only women can be journalists, only women can work in power plants?!.watThe second one... the cool thing in Tropico 3 is that you get to make your own "avatar" (i.e. your presidente persona) with a fairly nice variety of visual options, and you need to choose personal traits and flaws which have an effect on various factors in the game. Your avatar can be male or female, and being my troll self I of course picked female (I mean, is there something more boring than a male dictator, duh). And, well, in a little hilarious laziness on the developers' part, the traits are unchanged and all with descriptions written with a male character in mind... including the Womanizer flaw which remains completely unchanged. I mean, it's not impossible...But did I enjoy those 40 hours? Of course I did.And I miss Juanito already. ;_;

												An ambitious game, but ultimately fails due to difficulty, gameplay flaws (and fun value) and tedium.LONG VERSION:Okay, so I bought this game blindly because I heard tropico games are really really good. I install it, (ridiculously small file size, amazed me)I love the game at first. It's charming, hilarious, and fun. However, the more I played over the next few days, I had found that the flaws were really, really glaring. First of all, it seems like you HAVE to have a randomized map. Why? Why couldn't they just put a few more hours just to put the map editor that they used when making the game?Second, why can't I clear trees, rocks, and level terrain on my own? WHAT THE HELL WERE THEY THINKING?! Seriously..Thirdly, why is everything so tedious? It seems like after you have more than 100 people it starts to be a chore.The people are never happy, ever. I'd like to be able to lay back every once in a while and watch my people do their thing.Is that so much to ask?Finally, I feel like alot more could have been put into character creation. You are simply too limited to the point that I just barely was able to create Joseph Stalin (comrades 4ever), with his famous Stalin Stache. This isn't a biggy on my end, just that I'd like a little more customization.Last lastly: From what I can tell, there was alot of love and effort put into this game, but it simply doesn't do what it advertises, and that is city building.It's probably one of my biggest gripes about the game. Wanna build an airport on seemingly flat terrain? Nope! Can't do that, joe. Wanna build some houses nearby but not inside of rocks? Nope, the modellers didn't bother making collision models.  Wanna make more than one skyscraper? Nope! For whatever reason, you can't have a CITY that has skyscrapers. Also,skyscrapers are not skyscrapers. They're just really tall buildings.4/10.

												Tropico 3 is a well rounded economy simulator. Starting on small islands you have to build upwards with certain objectives or obstacles in your way. The game can be as simple or as complex as you decide since many of the subtle tools in your hand, as a kind Pacifist Leader or Ruthless Tyrant, are not necessary to win unless your wish to do so with style.The game offers a Caribbean like atmosphere, with rum, tobacco, coffee, pineapple industry etc. In addition to this the radio station will play island music and offer advise and advise you.To accomplish the objectives on each island you will have to balance the economical situation of salaries, food, population, health care, foreign diplomacy, housing, education and win the election. Now if you thought "This sounds perfect! Exactly the headache I want!" I warn you, after the 4th island you will realise that by following more or less the same routine you can create can economy to defeat every objective.The levels slowly become repetitive, the music is 4 songs over and over again. And the radio just repeats the same 5 attempts and "humour" again and again.However, I give it my recommendation since if played with moderation and you give each Island time and try not to rush you will have the illusion of going from a banana economy to Tyrant... 												At first glance, I thought this was going to be a generic city builder with the superficial fluff of playing a dictator to add a few laughs. However, Tropico 3 plays less like a city builder and more like a political simulator. Buildings aren't built to make money for more buildings or to create a better life for your citizens. No, buildings are built only to please the various factions and citizens of Tropico so fewer people consider having El Presidente retire to an 'undisclosed location'. The dictator context is mined for its laughs though and the game uses that sense of humor and a very helpful radio show to establish an instant sense of immersion which falls apart entirely when its variety is quickly exhasted. These extras go from endearing to repetitive all the way to obnoxious in the space of two or three missions. Character creation is where this lack of variety is the most glaring. There is a reasonably wide selection of appearances and traits to choose from, allowing for a real custom character. But with the text of those traits and the introduction of the missions being so specific, the character you've crafted floats away in the contradictions. This is not helped by the fact that El Presidente only has two sound sets, male and female, with the female being so cringe-worthy I only used it once. It is also worth mentioning that, as of the writing of this review, the 'Special Steam Edition' is thoroughly un-Steam. No Steam Achievements, No Trading Cards, No Cloud Saves. Nothing to indicate that this is a Steam game past the title. It doesn't change the way the game is played and Tropico 3 does have in game achievements to scratch that itch, but the lack of Steam features on a game so named seems a little strange. Complaints aside, I enjoyed playing this game, but I don't have plans to come back to it anytime soon. I recommend giving it go, but maybe play through the demo a few times before dropping any money on it.

												WHAT IF YOU WERE "EL PRESIDENTE"?I bought Tropico during 2013 Summer Sale and I only got around to playing it after playing several games ranging from action and racing to casual and stealth and I felt it was a good idea to play a city-builder game. So...GAMEPLAYTROPICO 3... is a fabulous and addicting game. It's all about being "El Presidente", managing an island banana republic and making it prosperous while embezzling some of the money for your Swiss bank account (which is non-crucial, it only serves for high score). You start every game by choosing your avatar, either pre-configured real ones like Che Guevara, Evita Peron and Voodoo Pizzaman or you can create your own. Then you start (always) with a banana republic which is in shambles and then you can do whatever with it by issuing edicts, constructing, pleasing different factions (like socially aware communists, hypocritical religious and more) and you rise through the difficulties and build a prosperous nation based on ore/coffee/rum/whatever exports... Or you pass a martial law and conscription edict and build a giant army... or ♥♥♥♥ off USA and make it invade you; the choices are many.CHARMNext, you have at first charming and humorous, but then repetitive Juanito who keeps Tropicans up to date on current issues, passed edicts and humorous event reports. The soundtrack is short but so sweet, you won't help but shimmy to the infectious salsa rhythm and graphics hold up pretty well (but it's a 2009 game, so it's kind of expected). The humor in this game is terrific and well though-out so you will definitely giggle at some of the event reports (like a llama assassinating El Presidente's favorite hat) and you will grow to curse at least one faction in this game. All of the mentioned elements make for a really freaking addicting game.MODESI first recommend playing the campaign mode, it is great to keep you occupied as you try to get through different goals and finish each island. The campaign mode definitely has some variety however even then, it will feel repetitive doing the same thing over and over again, just with a different end. The sandbox mode is great and there you can develop your island however you please and where you have your own ways of building a rich Carribean country.ITERATIONNow, it seems that this game is simply a remake of Tropico 1 and while I feel that's a good thing for newcomers, it brings nothing new to the table if you played the earlier games. Also, after a while it feels repetitive doing the same thing over and over again, you will eventually grow sick of it as every scenario you play starts the same.CONCLUSION+ Highly addictive and gratifying+ Salsa soundtrack+ Great humour+/- Remake of Tropico 1- Brings nothing new- Repetition8/10
